facts.text: Respondents' ancestors had been granted a cash allowance called Tainat by the Peshwas.
After defeat of Peshwas by British, Treaty of Gulgallee dated 6-6-1819 confirmed allowances including Tainat to Gopalrao Jamkhandikar; no complaints on this head to reach Government.
Allowance amounted to Rs. 2010/- minus Rs. 240/- being companymutation amount as per Petha Khata Wahi Extract of 1942-43; grant was permanent.
In 1944, ruler of Jamkhandi converted the allowance to one for life.
Jamkhandi State merged in State of Bombay.
Bombay Legislature passed Bombay Merged Territories Miscellaneous Alienations Abolition Act 1955.

Respondent filed application on 21-7-1956 under s.17 of the Act before Assistant Commissioner, Jamkhandi, claiming allowance permanent and hereditary; entitled to Rs.21,000/- (7 times Rs.3,000/-) or alternatively Rs.9,000/- (3 times for life); mentioned ruler's order to continue till his lifetime and pending application to Rajasaheb.
Assistant Commissioner granted sum respondent was receiving.

Respondent appealed to Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal (after area became part of Mysore State); claimed mistake in recording as for life only, pending application to Rajasaheb; argued ruler had no power to change as per 1909-10 order it was permanent.
Tribunal dismissed appeal, holding ruler had sovereign powers to change.
Respondent filed Writ Petition No. 777 of 1961 before Mysore High Court; claimed mistake in recording as for life, ruler had no power to interfere.
High Court directed payment of Rs.14,070 (7 times annual cash allowance of Rs.2010) on basis grant was hereditary; did not decide if ruler had power in 1944 to convert.
Extract from Jamkhandi State Gazette dated 7-8-1920 publishing rules on cash allowances, which cancelled earlier rules.
Rs.240 deduction was for companymutation amount for service replacement.

legal_issues.text: Whether the ruler of Jamkhandi had power in 1944 to convert permanent/hereditary cash allowance to one for life.
Whether Rs.240 companymutation amount is deductible in calculating compensation.
Constitutional validity of Bombay Merged Territories Miscellaneous Alienations Abolition Act 1955 (raised by respondent counsel).

petitioner_arguments.text: Ruler of Jamkhandi had sovereign powers to change permanent allowance to life; Mysore High Court erred in granting 7 times compensation without deciding power to convert; Rs.240 deductible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sovereign powers as in princely states pre-integration

respondent_arguments.text: Allowance permanent and hereditary per 1942-43 extract and 1909-10 order; mistake in recording as life; ruler had no power to change; entitled to 7 times compensation; Act violates Art.19(1)(f) and 31(2) as per M.P. case.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Petha Khata Wahi Extract; earlier ruler order 1909-10

court_reasoning.text: Ruler of Jamkhandi enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers pre-integration like Nizam of Hyderabad; could change grants at will; 1944 conversion valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ruler was supreme legislature, judiciary, executive; no constitutional limitations.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.240 companymutation deductible as per Petha Khata Wahi; High Court wrong to exclude it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deduction for service replacement; what was actually paid yearly.

court_reasoning.text: No opinion on constitutional challenge to Act; liberty to move High Court if advised.

holdings.text: Ruler's 1944 conversion of permanent Tainat to life allowance legally valid due to sovereign powers.
Compensation calculated on Rs.2010 minus Rs.240; Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal decision correct.

precedents_cited.relevance: Sets out constitutional position of rulers of Indian States pre-integration as having uncontrolled sovereign powers.
Held Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Cash Grants Act violates Art.19(1)(f) and 31(2); respondent sought similar for Bombay Act.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Merged Territories Miscellaneous Alienations Abolition Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Under which respondent claimed compensation; multiple of cash allowance based on permanent/hereditary or life.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged violation by the Abolition Act, analogous to M.P. case.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of Mysore High Court dated 30th November 1962 set aside; restored Tribunal decision granting 3 times net cash allowance after deducting Rs.240.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; High Court order quashed.

key_quotes.text: "It cannot be disputed that prior to the integration... the Nizam of Hyderabad enjoyed uncontrolled sovereign powers. He was the supreme legislature the supreme judiciary and the supreme head of the executive..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains sovereign powers of rulers justifying 1944 conversion.

key_quotes.text: "We are of opinion that clearly the decision of the Mysore High Court is wrong."
key_quotes.speaker: court
